data.title: The surprising meanings behind Portland’s most-unusual neighborhood names
data.meta_description: A high school student from Albany, New York has created an infographic with the stories behind Portland's neighborhood names.
data.text:
Do you know why Goose Hollow is called Goose Hollow? Or where the name Montavilla comes from? Adam Aleksic, a high school senior out of Albany, New York, does.

Aleksic loves etymology. He has a website dedicated to his love of words where he goes by the name “Etymology Nerd.”

Right now Aleksic is working on a project on city etymologies and one of the cities he’s turned his etymology-loving eye towards is Portland.

“I found this information from various sites online (Wikipedia, Mental Floss, city records),” Aleksic said over Twitter, about his sources, “and a couple times I had to call local libraries/information centers to confirm.”

Here are some of the interesting stories behind Portland’s most-unique neighborhood names that Aleksic has found.

Goose Hollow: According to Aleksic, “in 1875, there was a legal dispute over goose ownership in the commons here.”

Brooklyn: “Originally ‘Brookland,’ due to large number of creeks in the area,” according to Aleksic, “but as a lot of people moved in the nickname ‘Brooklyn’ took over.”

Montavilla: While you might think this is a Spanish word, Aleksic says it is in fact a “syllabic abbreviation of ‘Mount Tabor Village.’”

Mount Tabor: The lofty name of this high up neighborhood was, according to Aleksic, “named by local Methodists after the site in Israel where the transfiguration of Jesus was reported.”
